intro: Vaccinium iteophyllum var. fragrans, commonly known as the fragrant huckleberry, is a low-growing evergreen shrub native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes other familiar plants like blueberries and heathers. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically pink or white, followed by edible berries that are dark blue to black in color. It thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and prefers partial to full shade, making it a common understory plant in coniferous forests. Its fragrant foliage and ornamental berries make it a valued plant in both natural and cultivated landscapes.
